title: Do Not Camp Under A Blood Moon. Strange Things Happen.
full_text: I stared at my kitchen calendar, my eyes fixed on the weekend circled in bright red marker. The bold circle sat there like a warning sign, counting down the days until I'd be dragged into the wilderness. Nancy had marked it with little stars and a crescent moon doodle. Her excitement visible in the heavy pen strokes that had nearly torn through the paper. "It's just two nights," I muttered to myself, taking a sip of coffee that had already gone cold. Two nights of sleeping on the ground, two nights of whatever crawled, slithered, or prowled through Blackwood National Forest. Two nights without a proper bathroom. But I loved Nancy. That was the simple truth that had me packing a backpack instead of making excuses. In the year we'd been dating, I'd learned that her passion for the outdoors was as much a part of her as her laugh, or the way she tucked her hair behind her ear when she was thinking. Nancy had been talking about this trip for weeks. "Jake, it's a blood moon weekend," she'd said. Her amber eyes lighting up the way they always did when she talked about celestial events. "We can't miss it. The forest under a blood moon, it'll be magical." Magic wasn't exactly what I was worried about. Ticks, poison ivy, and bears seemed more likely. The morning of our departure came too quickly. Nancy arrived at my apartment with her truck already loaded with gear, wearing a smile that made it impossible to back out. "Ready for an adventure?" she asked, kissing me on the cheek as she walked past me into my apartment to grab my backpack. "As ready as I'll ever be," I said, forcing enthusiasm I didn't feel. I locked my apartment door behind us, each click of the deadbolt feeling like a farewell to safety and indoor plumbing. The drive to Blackwood took three hours, winding through increasingly remote areas until even the radio stations turned to static. I gripped the steering wheel tightly as the road narrowed and twisted up the mountain, focusing all my attention on not driving us off a cliff. Nancy meanwhile, seemed completely at ease. Her feet propped on the dashboard as she pointed out landmarks and talked about what we might see in the night sky. "The blood moon happens during a total lunar eclipse," she explained, her fingers tracing invisible patterns in the air. "The Earth's shadow falls across the moon, but some sunlight still filters through our atmosphere. All the blue light gets scattered away, leaving only the red light to reach the moon." I nodded, only half listening as I navigated a particularly sharp turn. "Sounds pretty," I managed, braking more sharply than I intended when a deer bounded across the road ahead. "It's more than pretty," Nancy continued, unfazed by our near miss with wildlife. "Blood moons have cultural significance in almost every ancient civilization. Some saw it as an omen, others as a time when the barrier between worlds thins." "That's comforting," I said dryly, earning a playful punch to my shoulder. We reached the trailhead around noon. The parking area was empty except for one dusty pickup truck at the far end. As I pulled into a spot, I noticed a weathered sign with a map of the forest trails and warnings about wildlife. Nancy was already unloading gear before I'd turned off the engine. She moved with practiced efficiency, sorting through equipment and distributing weight between packs. It was clear she'd done this countless times before. "My dad taught me everything about camping," she said when she caught me watching her. Emmett could probably survive in the wilderness with just a pocketknife and his wits. We used to go camping at least once a month when I was growing up. I tried to imagine Nancy as a little girl learning to pitch a tent or start a fire under her father's watchful eye. The image made me smile despite my apprehension. "Here," she said, handing me what looked like an enormous backpack. "You take the tent and cooking gear. I've got the food and everything else." I nearly toppled over when I shouldered the pack. "Jesus, Nancy. Are we camping or moving in?" She laughed, adjusting the straps on my shoulders with expert hands. "Trust me. You'll be glad we brought everything when you're warm and well-fed tonight." The trail started gently enough, a dirt path winding between tall pines. Nancy took the lead, moving with the sure-footed confidence of someone who belonged in these woods. I followed behind, already feeling sweat dampen my shirt under the weight of the pack. "How much farther?" I asked after what felt like hours of hiking uphill. Nancy checked her watch. "We've only been walking for 45 minutes, city boy," she teased, "but we've got another hour or so to go. I want to find the perfect spot before we lose the light." By the time Nancy finally stopped in a small clearing, my legs were burning and my shoulders ached from the pack. I dropped to the ground with a groan of relief while she surveyed the area with a critical eye. "This is perfect," she declared, turning in a slow circle. "Good tree coverage, flat ground for the tent, and an open view of the sky for when the moon rises." I looked around, trying to see what made this particular patch of forest floor better than any other we'd passed. The clearing was ringed by tall pines and a few deciduous trees I couldn't name. A fallen log lay at one edge, already being reclaimed by moss and fungi. As I caught my breath, something struck me as odd. I held perfectly still, listening. Nothing, absolutely nothing."Nancy," I said quietly, "do you notice anything strange?" She looked up from where she was already unpacking the tent. "Strange how?" "It's completely silent. No birds, no insects, nothing." Nancy paused, tilting her head as if to listen better. Then she laughed, the sound jarringly loud in the quiet forest. "Wildlife usually steers clear of human activity," she said, resuming her unpacking. "They probably heard us coming from a mile away. Nothing to worry about." I nodded, accepting her explanation because she was the expert. But something about the silence felt wrong, oppressive even. In movies, animals going quiet was never a good sign. "Come help me with the tent," Nancy called, interrupting my thoughts. "I'll show you how to set it up properly." For the next hour, we worked on making our camp. Nancy taught me how to pitch the tent, finding the flattest ground and securing the stakes properly. She showed me how to hang our food bag from a tree branch to keep it away from bears, a thought that did nothing to ease my anxiety. As the afternoon wore on, I kept expecting the forest sounds to return, the chirp of birds, the buzz of insects, the rustle of small animals in the underbrush, but the silence persisted, broken only by our voices and movements. We finished setting up camp as the daylight began to fade. Nancy got a small camping stove going and started preparing dinner, some kind of pasta with dried vegetables that smelled surprisingly good after hours of physical exertion. "See? Not so bad, right?" Nancy asked, handing me a steaming bowl. "The company makes it bearable," I admitted, which earned me a smile. We sat side by side on the fallen log, eating our dinner as darkness settled around us. But even as we talked quietly about mundane things, work, friends, plans for the coming week, I couldn't shake my uneasiness. The forest remained unnaturally quiet as if holding its breath. Every so often, I would pause in our conversation, straining to hear any natural sound from the woods around us. Nothing, not even the wind in the trees. "You're still thinking about the silence, aren't you?" Nancy asked, noticing my distraction. "It just doesn't seem right," I said. "Shouldn't we hear something? Anything?" Nancy set her empty bowl aside and took my hand. "Forests can be quiet, Jake, especially at dusk when diurnal animals are settling down and nocturnal ones haven't come out yet. It's normal." I wanted to believe her. I nodded and squeezed her hand, but the silence still felt wrong to me. It wasn't the peaceful quiet of nature at rest. It felt deliberate, watchful. As we cleaned up after dinner, storing everything carefully to avoid attracting animals, I kept glancing at the darkening woods around our little clearing. The trees seemed to press closer in the growing darkness, their shadows stretching toward our campsite like grasping fingers. "You're going to love the blood moon," Nancy said oblivious to my discomfort as she checked her watch. "It should be rising in a couple of hours. We'll have the perfect view right from our campsite." I forced a smile, not wanting to dampen her enthusiasm with my irrational unease. After all, she was the experienced one. If Nancy wasn't worried about the silence, maybe I was just being paranoid, my city instincts misreading the normal rhythms of the forest. But as night fully claimed the woods around us, the silence only seemed to deepen, becoming almost physical in its intensity. And despite Nancy's reassurances, I couldn't shake the feeling that something in the darkness was watching us, waiting with a patience I couldn't comprehend. I watched the blood moon rise above the tree line. The forest had been quiet all day, but now as darkness settled fully around us, that silence felt heavier, more intentional. The moon emerged slowly, a massive crimson disc that seemed too large, too close as it climbed into the night sky. "Look at how the Earth's shadow is moving across it," Nancy said, pointing upward. "The red color comes from sunlight passing through our atmosphere and bending around the Earth." I nodded, genuinely impressed despite the unease growing in my stomach. "It's beautiful," I admitted. The red glow bathed everything around us, the trees, our tent, Nancy's face, in an unsettling crimson light that made familiar shapes seem alien. "Ancient civilizations thought blood moons were omens," Nancy continued, her voice carrying easily in the stillness. "The Mayans believed they signaled cosmic shifts. Some cultures thought they mark the boundary between our world and something else." I wish she hadn't added that last part. My mother, Judy, had filled my childhood with similar warnings, stories about things that lurked in the spaces between worlds, especially on nights when the moon turned red. I dismissed those tales as I grew up, but standing here under this blood-red sky, they suddenly felt less like superstition and more like forgotten wisdom. We sat on the fallen log, eating the granola bars and dried fruit we'd packed for a late snack, barely speaking. The oppressive quiet made normal conversation feel wrong somehow, intrusive. I caught myself whispering without knowing why."Why are we whispering?" Nancy asked, also in a whisper. "I don't know," I admitted. "It just feels right." She nodded, understanding. The silence around us wasn't just the absence of sound. It felt like something actively listening. Around 10:00, we crawled into our tent and slipped into our sleeping bags. The ground beneath me was hard and uneven despite the sleeping pad Nancy had insisted I bring. I shifted positions a dozen times, trying to get comfortable while Nancy fell asleep almost immediately. I stared at the red-tinted ceiling of our tent, watching shadows from the trees move across it like grasping fingers. Eventually, exhaustion overcame discomfort, and I drifted off. My dreams were disturbing. Red light filtered through dense trees as I ran from something I couldn't see. Shadowy figures stood just beyond my vision, watching and waiting. My mother's voice echoed through the dreamscape, "They hunt under the blood moon, Jake. They've been hunting since before we had names for them." In my dream, I was a child again, sitting on my bed while Mom checked under it for monsters. "How do you know they're real?" I asked her. "Because I've seen them," she whispered, her eyes wide and serious. "Under the blood moon, they look almost like us, but they move wrong, and they're hungry, Jake, so hungry." A sharp sound jolted me awake. I opened my eyes to the dark interior of the tent, momentarily disoriented. The red glow of the blood moon still filtered through the fabric, casting everything in dim crimson. I lay perfectly still, my heart pounding as I listened. There it was again, footsteps crunching softly on leaves outside our tent. The movement seemed too deliberate for a wild animal. Animals moved with purpose, seeking food or water, then moving on. These footsteps were exploratory, curious. I checked my watch, 2:00 in the morning. The footsteps continued circling our campsite. I nudged Nancy's shoulder gently. "Nancy," I whispered, my voice barely audible. "Wake up." She stirred, rolling toward me. "What's wrong?" she murmured, her voice thick with sleep. "There's something outside," I whispered. "Listen." We both went silent. The footsteps continued their slow circuit around our tent. "It's just a deer," Nancy said after a moment, but she didn't sound convinced. "Deer don't circle like that," I replied. "They don't investigate." We lay still, listening, as the footsteps continued their methodical pattern. Whatever was out there circled our tent completely, then started another loop. The third time around, I began counting. By the 12th circuit, my mouth had gone dry with fear. Then the footsteps stopped directly in front of the tent entrance. The silence that followed was worse than the footsteps. I could feel Nancy's body tense beside me as we both stared at the zippered doorway, waiting. I stared in disbelief as Nancy suddenly reached for the zipper, pulling it down with deliberate movements. She didn't acknowledge my frantic whispers as she crawled outside, leaving me alone in the tent. The sound of the zipper seemed unnaturally loud against the backdrop of complete silence. "Nancy," I whispered urgently. "What are you doing? Come back." No response came, just the soft sound of her footsteps moving away from the tent. I waited, counting the minutes on my watch, hoping she just stepped out briefly to use the bathroom or check something. One minute passed, then three, then five. My anxiety grew with each passing second. This wasn't like Nancy at all. She was too experienced to wander off alone in the middle of the night. After waiting what felt like forever, I made up my mind. I had to follow her. I crawled toward the tent opening, my hands shaking as I pushed aside the flap. The sight that greeted me stole my breath. The blood moon hung directly overhead, massive and impossibly red. Its crimson light poured down through the trees, transforming our campsite into something from a nightmare. Every surface, the tent, the trees, my own hands was bathed in that sickly red glow. I stepped out fully, my eyes adjusting to the strange light. That's when I spotted her. Nancy stood about 20 feet from our tent, completely motionless. Her back was to me, her face tilted upward. She wore only the T-shirt and shorts she'd gone to sleep in, her feet bare against the forest floor. "Nancy," I called, louder this time, no longer concerned about keeping quiet. Something was very wrong. She didn't move, didn't acknowledge me at all. I approached her slowly, repeatedly saying her name. "Nancy. Nancy, can you hear me? What's going on?" No matter how many times I called to her, she remained completely unresponsive. It was as if she couldn't hear me at all. The closer I got, the more unnerving the sight became. Her body was rigid, unnaturally still. When I finally reached her, I hesitated before touching her. Her face was blank, expressionless, her eyes wide open and staring upward. Those eyes, I'll never forget how they looked. They reflected the red moonlight like mirrors, giving her an otherworldly, almost inhuman appearance."Nancy, please," I said, reaching out to touch her shoulder. Her skin felt wrong under my fingers, cold and clammy despite the warm night air. It was like touching someone who'd been standing in a freezer. I followed her gaze upward, expecting to see that she was transfixed by the blood moon itself, but her focus wasn't on the moon at all. She was looking at something else, something in the forest beyond our campsite. I turned slowly following the direction of her stare, and that's when I saw it, or rather, her. There was a woman standing among the trees. She stood about 50 yards away, just close enough that I could make out her silhouette and some details, but far enough that her features remained indistinct in the shadows. She wore tattered, flowing clothes that moved and rippled despite the complete absence of wind. Her long hair hung in tangled strands around her face, which remained obscured in darkness. The woman was completely motionless, just like Nancy. But unlike Nancy, I could feel her awareness, her attention. She was watching us, watching me. I couldn't see her eyes, but I could feel them on me, studying us with an intensity that made my skin crawl. She made no move to approach, no gesture to communicate. She simply stood there, partially hidden among the trees, observing us with what felt like hungry interest. I wanted to run, to grab Nancy and drag her back to the safety of our tent, but I couldn't move. I couldn't even speak. We were caught in some kind of terrible tableau. Nancy staring at the woman, the woman staring back at us, and me frozen between them, the only one aware of how wrong this all was. The woman's clothes continued to move and flow around her body as if she were underwater. Her hair too seemed to drift and sway despite the still night air. Everything about her was wrong. Her stillness, her presence, the impossible movement of her garments. I couldn't see her face clearly, but something told me I didn't want to. Something told me that if I got close enough to make out her features, I'd regret it for the rest of my life. I reached for Nancy's arm, grabbing it more firmly than I'd ever held her before. My fingers wrapped around her cold skin as I tried pulling her back toward our tent. "Nancy, we need to go now." My voice cracked barely above a whisper. She didn't respond. Her body remained rigid, eyes fixed on that woman at the forest's edge. When I tugged harder, Nancy resisted with a strength I didn't know she had. Her feet seemed planted to the ground, her body leaning slightly forward as if drawn by an invisible thread connecting her to the stranger. I pulled again, harder this time. "Nancy, please. Something's wrong. We need to get back to the tent." The moonlight cast everything in that sickening red glow, making Nancy's blank expression look almost mask-like. She gave no indication she'd heard me at all. That's when I noticed movement from the corner of my eye. The woman had started to move. She didn't walk, not exactly. She glided between the trees with a fluid motion that made my stomach turn. Her feet, they didn't seem to touch the ground. Each step carried her sideways, then forward in a pattern that no human joints could manage. Yet she never stumbled, never paused. Her tattered clothes continued their underwater rippling despite the still air. I watched paralyzed as she began a wide arc around our campsite. She maintained her distance, never coming closer, but never retreating either. Her face remained hidden behind that curtain of tangled hair, but I knew I could feel her eyes on us, watching, studying. The realization hit me like ice water. She was hunting us, learning our movements, looking for weaknesses, testing Nancy's connection to whatever hold she had on her. My heart hammered against my ribs. This wasn't some random encounter. This was calculated, deliberate. "Fuck this," I muttered, abandoning any pretense of gentle persuasion. I moved behind Nancy and wrapped both arms around her waist. Using every ounce of strength I had, I lifted her off the ground. She was surprisingly light, but she thrashed against me immediately, her arms flailing and legs kicking out. "Nancy, stop, please," I grunted, struggling to maintain my grip. Her elbow caught me in the ribs, sending a sharp pain through my side, but I didn't let go. I half carried, half dragged her backward toward our tent, my eyes never leaving the woman who continued her unnatural circling. She turned her head to track our movement, that hidden face always pointed in our direction. Nancy's resistance was unlike anything I'd experienced from her before. Her normally gentle demeanor had transformed into something feral and desperate. She clawed at my arms, leaving red welts across my skin. The 10 yards back to our tent felt like a mile. My lungs burned from the effort and fear. When my back finally hit the tent fabric, I fumbled one hand behind me to find the zipper while keeping my other arm locked around Nancy's waist. I managed to get the tent flap open just enough. With one final surge of desperate strength, I pulled us both through the opening and onto our sleeping bags. Nancy immediately tried to scramble back toward the entrance, but I threw myself on top of her, using my weight to pin her down.I reached back and yanked the zipper closed with such force I thought it might break off in my hand. "Nancy, stop. Please, stop," I begged, holding her against me. Her struggling continued for what felt like minutes, but was probably only seconds. Then, gradually, I felt the tension leave her body. The rigid posture softened. Her breathing, which had been shallow and rapid, deepened and slowed. I kept my arms around her, afraid to let go, my own breath coming in ragged gasps. We lay there on top of our sleeping bags, a tangle of limbs and fear. After a long moment, I felt Nancy shift. She turned her head, blinking slowly as if waking from a deep sleep. "Jake?" Her voice sounded normal again. Confused, but Nancy. "Why are we awake? What's going on?" I loosened my grip slightly, but didn't let go entirely. "You don't remember?" She pushed herself up to a sitting position, rubbing her eyes. "Remember what? I was asleep." My hands shook as I sat up beside her. The red moonlight filtered through our tent, casting everything in that bloody glow. Outside, the forest had fallen silent again. "Nancy, you... You walked out of the tent in the middle of the night. You just got up, unzipped the door, and walked out. I followed you and found you standing in the clearing, staring at..." I swallowed hard. The image of the woman's unnatural movement fresh in my mind. "At what?" Nancy asked, looking genuinely confused. "There was a woman in the woods, standing at the edge of the trees, watching us. And you were just... Staring at her, like you were in some kind of trance. When I tried to bring you back, you fought me." Nancy's brow furrowed. "Jake, I don't remember any of that. The last thing I remember is falling asleep." "But it happened. She was right there, wearing these tattered clothes that moved like they were under water. And she started circling our camp, watching us like... Like she was hunting us." Nancy reached out and took my hand. Her skin felt warm now, normal. "Jake, listen to me. You probably had a nightmare, a really vivid one." "It wasn't a dream," I insisted, my voice rising. "I was awake the whole time. I saw her. I saw you standing there, looking at her with this blank expression. Your eyes were reflecting the moonlight, like... Like they weren't even your eyes." Nancy squeezed my hand. "Think about it. We're in an unfamiliar place, sleeping on the ground. There's this weird silence in the forest that's been making you uneasy all day, and now there's this creepy red moon. Your brain probably took all that stress and turned it into a nightmare." "But..." "It happens all the time," she continued. "Stress and unfamiliar surroundings can cause really realistic dreams. Sometimes people even sleepwalk or think they're awake when they're not." I wanted to believe her. Part of me desperately wanted this to be a nightmare, something I could laugh about in the morning. But I knew what I'd seen. The woman's unnatural movements, Nancy's cold skin and vacant stare, the way she'd fought against me with strength that didn't seem like her own. "It felt real," I said quietly. Nancy shifted closer, putting her arm around my shoulders. "I know. And I'm not saying you're making it up. I'm just saying our brains can play tricks on us, especially in places like this." I looked toward the tent door, still zipped shut. Outside, there was nothing but silence, and that red glow seeping through the fabric. Had I imagined it all? The alternative, that something inhuman was circling our camp, that it had somehow taken control of Nancy, seemed too horrifying to accept. "Maybe you're right," I said, not believing it, but wanting the comfort of a rational explanation. Nancy smiled softly. "Let's try to get some sleep, okay? Everything will seem clearer in the morning." She lay back down on her sleeping bag, pulling me with her. I settled beside her, my body still tense, ears straining for any sound from outside. "It just seemed so real," I whispered. "That's how nightmares work," Nancy replied, her voice already growing drowsy. "They convince you they're real until you wake up." I didn't argue further. But as Nancy's breathing evened out into sleep beside me, I kept my eyes open, staring at the tent ceiling, watching the shadows move across the red-tinted fabric. I couldn't shake the feeling that the woman was still out there, circling, waiting. And I couldn't forget the look in Nancy's eyes, empty and reflecting, like something else had been looking through them. I insisted I'd been fully awake and the woman was real, but Nancy's skepticism made me doubt myself. I lay rigid in my sleeping bag, straining to hear anything outside our tent while Nancy's breathing had already settled into the deep rhythm of sleep beside me. "I know what I saw," I whispered to myself, though the words sounded hollow in the confines of our tent. The red moonlight still filtered through the thin fabric, casting everything in that unnatural crimson glow. I checked my watch, just past 3:00 in the morning. Hours until dawn,... my arms still stung from the welts Nancy's nails had left when I dragged her back to safety, physical evidence that something had happened regardless of what she claimed. Every few minutes, I'd freeze at what I thought was a sound outside, a twig snapping, fabric rustling, only to be met with that same oppressive silence that had unnerved me since we'd arrived. I kept my eyes locked on the tent zipper, half expecting it to slowly pull down on its own, revealing that woman's face with her tangled hair and flowing clothes. Nancy shifted in her sleep, mumbling something unintelligible before settling again. I envied her peace. How could she sleep so soundly after what happened? Or maybe nothing had happened to her. Maybe I really was losing my mind out here in the wilderness. I pulled my sleeping bag up higher, creating a barrier between myself and whatever might be lurking outside, though I knew the thin nylon offered no real protection. The hard ground beneath my sleeping pad seemed to grow more uncomfortable with each passing hour, every root and stone making itself known against my back. Sometime during those endless hours, exhaustion must have overcome vigilance because I startled awake to Nancy moving around the tent. Sunlight, normal yellow sunlight, was streaming through the fabric. "Morning," Nancy said cheerfully, already half-dressed in her hiking clothes. "You look terrible. Bad dreams?" I sat up disoriented. "What time is it?" "Almost 7:00. I was going to let you sleep a bit longer, but we should get moving if we want to make it back to the trailhead by noon." I rubbed my face, trying to process the normalcy of the morning against the strangeness of the night. Outside the tent, I could hear birds calling to each other, their songs overlapping in the morning chorus. Somewhere nearby, something small, a squirrel maybe, rustled through the underbrush. "Do you hear that?" I asked. Nancy paused while pulling on her sock. "Hear what?" "The birds, the animals. Everything's making noise again." She looked at me strangely. "Yeah. That's what happens in forests, Jake." "But yesterday..." I stopped myself. "Never mind." I crawled out of my sleeping bag and found my clothes, changing quickly while Nancy stepped outside to take down the food bags she'd hung from the trees. The normal sounds of the forest were almost as unsettling as the silence had been, simply because of how abruptly they'd returned. When I emerged from the tent, the clearing looked completely different in the morning light. Dew sparkled on the grass and shafts of sunlight cut through the tree canopy. Nothing about this peaceful scene suggested the terrifying encounter from last night. Nancy was efficiently rolling up her sleeping bag when I approached her. "About last night-" "Jake," she cut me off with a sigh. "I told you it was just a nightmare. You were stressed about being out here and your brain played tricks on you. It happens." "But you were outside. I had to drag you back in. Look." I pushed up my sleeve to show her the welts on my arm, but they had faded to faint pink lines, barely visible in the morning light. "They were redder last night," I said lamely. Nancy shook her head. "You probably scratched yourself on a branch or something when we were setting up camp." She went back to packing, moving with practiced efficiency. "Can you take down the tent? I want to get going before it gets too hot." I stood there for a moment, wanting to argue but lacking the evidence to make my case. Eventually, I turned to the tent and began removing the stakes, feeling increasingly foolish. Had I really imagined the whole thing? The woman with her unnatural movements, Nancy's trance-like state, the struggle to get her back inside. As Nancy continued breaking camp, talking about the trail conditions and what we might have for lunch when we got back to town, I found myself wondering if maybe she was right. Maybe the stress of being in an unfamiliar environment combined with my anxiety and the strange silence had created a perfect storm for a vivid hallucination. While Nancy was busy organizing our backpacks, I walked to the edge of the clearing to the exact spot where I'd seen the woman standing. The ground there looked undisturbed. No footprints, no broken branches, no sign that anyone had been there at all. I crouched down, running my fingers through the leaves and dirt, searching for any evidence. "What are you doing?" Nancy called from across the clearing. I straightened up quickly. "Nothing, just checking something." "Well, hurry up. I'm almost done packing." I took one last look at the tree line, then rejoined Nancy by our dismantled campsite. She had already packed most of our gear, the tent being the last major item. I folded it methodically, trying to match the neat creases from when we'd first unpacked it. "You're quiet this morning," Nancy observed as she handed me a granola bar. I accepted it with a nod. "Just tired. Didn't sleep well." "I slept great," she said, stretching her arms overhead. "Something about the fresh air, I guess." As we shouldered our packs and prepared to leave, I took one final scan of our campsite, looking for anything we might've missed or any sign of what I'd experienced. The clearing looked pristine, as if we'd never been there at all. The hike back was easier than the trek in, mostly downhill and in daylight.... Nancy walked ahead of me on the narrow trail, pointing out interesting plants or bird calls. I responded with non-committal sounds. My attention divided between watching the path and constantly checking behind us. "You keep looking over your shoulder," Nancy said after I'd done it for perhaps the 20th time. "Are you worried we're being followed by a bear or something?" "No. Just..." I struggled to find an explanation that wouldn't sound crazy. "Just making sure we're not dropping anything." She gave me a look that said she didn't believe me, but decided not to push it. "We're making good time. Should be back at the car in about 40 minutes." I nodded, adjusting my pack straps. Every time we rounded a bend in the trail or passed through a particularly dense section of forest, I felt my shoulders tense, half expecting to see that woman standing there. Her tattered clothes moving despite the still air. But there was nothing, just trees, rocks, and the occasional startled bird taking flight at our approach. The normal forest sounds continued around us, almost mockingly ordinary after the unnatural silence of yesterday. Squirrels chattered overhead, birds called back and forth, and insects buzzed among the undergrowth. Everything was as it should be in a forest, which only made my memory of the previous night seem more like a dream. "So, I was thinking," Nancy said as we navigated around a fallen tree. "Maybe next month we could try that three-day loop trail on the eastern side of the park. There's supposed to be some amazing views from the ridge." I nearly stumbled. "You wanna come back here?" "Well, not exactly here, but yeah, same park. Why not? Apart from your nightmare, it was a pretty perfect trip, don't you think?" I didn't answer immediately, focusing instead on a tricky section of trail where exposed roots created natural steps down a steep incline. The thought of returning to these woods, especially with the possibility of another blood moon, made my stomach tighten with dread. "I don't know," I finally said. "Maybe we could try somewhere else next time, a different park maybe." Nancy glanced back at me with a small frown. "You're really shaken up by that dream, aren't you?" "It wasn't a dream," I said automatically, then regretted it when her expression shifted to concern. "Jake, I promise you, nothing happened last night. We went to sleep, and then we woke up this morning. That's it." I wanted to believe her. It would be easier to accept that I'd had a vivid nightmare than to believe that some unnatural woman had been watching us from the woods, that Nancy had been in some kind of trance, drawn to this entity like a moth to flame. "Yeah," I said finally. "You're probably right." We continued down the trail, and I kept looking back over my shoulder, unable to shake the feeling of being watched. Each time, I saw nothing but the empty trail behind us, dappled with morning sunlight filtering through the trees. I couldn't shake the feeling of being watched as I hiked back to the trailhead with Nancy. Every few minutes, I glanced over my shoulder, scanning the trees behind us. The forest sounds had returned, birds calling, leaves rustling, but that only made me more uneasy after yesterday's unnatural silence. "You keep looking back," Nancy said, pausing to wait for me on the trail. "Did you drop something?" "No, just checking." I hurried to catch up with her, my backpack straps digging into my shoulders. The sensation of eyes on my back stayed with me for the entire hike. I kept my focus on Nancy's blue backpack ahead of me, counting steps to distract myself. Forty-five minutes later, we finally broke through the tree line into the parking lot. Our car sat where we'd left it, alongside the dusty pickup truck. Its mouth opened wider than any mouth should, revealing not teeth, but a deeper darkness within, a void that seemed to pull at something inside me. I couldn't look away. Those eyes fixed on mine, and I felt a pressure building in my head, a silent demand to step outside the circle, to bring Nancy with me. "No," I said, the word barely audible even to myself. The entity lunged forward with impossible speed, a final desperate attempt to reach us. It slammed against our invisible barrier, and it shattered. Like glass breaking into a thousand pieces, its form fragmented and dissolved into mist. A scream tore through the forest, high-pitched and inhuman, making my ears ring painfully. The sound faded slowly, echoing between the trees until silence returned. Nancy's body went limp in my arms. The convulsions stopped as suddenly as they had begun. I dropped the sage, now burned down to almost nothing, and cradled her face in my hands. "Nancy? Nancy, can you hear me?" Her eyelids fluttered, then opened. Her eyes were clear, truly clear for the first time in weeks. The vacant stare was gone, replaced by confusion and recognition. "Jake?" she whispered, her voice hoarse. "What... Where are we?" She looked around, taking in the dark forest and the circle of iron nails surrounding us. "Why are we back here?" Relief flooded through me so intensely I almost cried. "You're back," I said, pulling her against my chest. "You're really back." "I don't understand," she said, pushing away slightly to look at my face. "Did something happen? Your ears, they're bleeding." I touched my ear, and my fingers came away red. The entity's final scream must've done physical damage. "It's okay," I assured her. "Everything's okay now." "The last thing I remember clearly is..." She frowned, concentrating. "We were at home. I was standing at the window y- looking at the moon. And there was something else there, watching me. Watching through me." She shuddered. "After that, everything's in pieces. Fragments of dreams, or not dreams." "Something followed us home from our last trip here," I explained, keeping my arms around her. "It was affecting you, changing you. I had to bring us back to fix it." "The woman," Nancy whispered, her eyes widening. "The woman in the woods. She was in my head, Jake, talking to me. Using my hands to collect things, arrange them. Using my mouth to say words I didn't understand." Her hands clutched at my jacket. "Parts of me feel missing, like there are holes where memories should be." "That's still you," I said firmly. "All you. The holes will fill in with time." We stayed inside the protective circle for the rest of the night. Neither of us suggested leaving until daylight came. Nancy drifted in and out of sleep against my shoulder while I kept watch, my ears still ringing, dried blood crusted on my neck. The iron nails remained undisturbed around us, and I didn't dare move them until morning. Nancy told me about fragments she remembered, standing at our apartment window for hours without knowing why,... collecting strange objects from parks and roadsides without remembering doing it, dreams of a woman watching her from the corner of every room. She remembered voices in her head that weren't hers, urging her to do things, say things. "Am I myself again?" she asked at one point, her voice small in the darkness. "Yes," I told her, though I couldn't be completely sure. "You're you." When the first light of dawn filtered through the trees, we finally felt safe enough to stand. My legs were stiff and numb from sitting on the hard ground all night. Nancy was unsteady on her feet, leaning against me for support. We packed our few belongings quickly, neither of us wanting to spend another minute in that clearing. The hike out was silent. Birds had returned to the forest, their calls a welcome reminder of normal life. The trail seemed shorter in daylight, less threatening. By the time we reached the parking lot, the sun was fully up, turning the morning mist golden. As we loaded our gear into the car, I looked back at the forest one last time. It looked ordinary now, just trees and underbrush, but I knew better. I knew what waited in there, or things like it, ancient and patient and hungry. Maybe we had banished this particular entity, but others existed. They waited in the spaces between worlds, in forgotten places, in the silence that falls when all natural sounds cease. "I'm never coming back here," I said quietly, more to myself than to Nancy. "Not to Blackwood, not to any wilderness during a blood moon." Nancy nodded, her face pale but determined. "We'll stay in the city when the moon turns red," she agreed, "where there's light and noise and people." As we drove away, I couldn't shake the memory of that face. Too many eyes, that impossible mouth. I knew it would visit my nightmares for years to come. Some knowledge can't be unlearned. Some sights can't be unseen. We would carry this with us forever, the understanding that the world is stranger and more dangerous than most people ever realize, and that ancient things still hunt in forgotten places.
